item.title: Endlessh : Troll any hacker with this cool SSH blackhole !
item.author: Author
item.description: Firewalls, brute force detection, SSH on random port, geoip filtering, honeypots… There are LOTS of ideas to make life hard for the bot army that constantly probes the internet. Well, thanks to “skeeto” you can add “Endlessh” to this list ! How does it work ? According to the official Github repository, Endlessh is an SSH tarpit that very slowly sends an endless, random SSH banner. It keeps SSH clients locked up for hours or even days at a time.

item.title: PPA & AUR : A security hole in Ubuntu & Arch Linux ?
item.author: Author
item.description: Arch Linux and Ubuntu are both excellent distributions whose security is taken very seriously by their people, but these two behemoths both have a BIG Achilles heel. First things first Don’t get me wrong folks, I really like the philosophy behind those two distributions : Making Linux accessible to anyone for Ubuntu Pushing customization to the limit for Arch Linux (as long as we have nothing against systemd) I also spent a lot of time on these two distributions using them as daily drivers, and they are both great !

item.title: Don't be fooled by this kind of UNIX-like backdoors
item.author: Author
item.description: I am seeing more and more attacks in the wild implying the use of a setuid mechanism to maintain a privileged access onto a UNIX-like system (Linux, BSD’s, OSX, etc.). A little bit of context Let’s imagine your system being hacked by any kind, it could be either : An unfortunate weak password guess A malicious physical access A chad NSA 0day slamming your ports … As you are someone who knows a little bit about IT security, you successfully manage to patch your system and change all your passwords, locking out the hackers.
